---
slug: /235
title: "This Week In React #235: React Router, createStore, SuspenseList, Transition Indicator, Compiler, RenderHooks, Waku, React-Scan | Expo, Lava, Fortnite, Skia, AI, Lynx | TC39, using, Zod, Node, Deno"
authors: [slorber]
date: 05-21-2025
---
Hi everyone!

This week, we're delighted to finally have a preview of React Server Components support in React Router. I've also found some very interesting PRs on the React repo, and give you a glimpse of what could be coming soon!

translations.fr: Cette semaine, nous sommes ravis d'avoir enfin un aper√ßu de la prise en charge des React Server Components dans React Router. J'ai √©galement trouv√© des PR tr√®s int√©ressantes sur le d√©p√¥t React, et je vous donne un aper√ßu de ce qui pourrait arriver bient√¥t !

segments.source_content: ## ‚öõÔ∏è React {#react}
[![React Router RSC Preview](/emails/issues/235/rr.jpg)](https://remix.run/blog/rsc-preview)
**[React Router RSC Preview](https://remix.run/blog/rsc-preview)**

The React Router team unveiled a preview of React Server Components support using the Parcel bundler. Stable support is blocked until Vite officially supports RSCs, but the good news is that React Router is becoming more framework-agnostic, and they expect to support other bundlers in the future with minimal effort.

translations.fr: L'√©quipe React Router a d√©voil√© un aper√ßu de la prise en charge des React Server Components avec le bundler Parcel. Le support stable est bloqu√© jusqu'√† ce que Vite prenne officiellement en charge les RSC, mais React Router devient plus agnostique aux frameworks et pr√©voit de supporter d'autres bundlers avec un effort minimal.
translations.en: L'√©quipe React Router a d√©voil√© un aper√ßu du support des React Server Components utilisant le bundler Parcel. Le support stable est bloqu√© jusqu'√† ce que Vite prenne officiellement en charge les RSC, mais la bonne nouvelle est que React Router devient plus agnostique vis-√†-vis des frameworks, et ils pr√©voient de supporter d'autres bundlers √† l'avenir avec un effort minimal.

segments.source_content: The feature is designed to be both incrementally adoptable by returning JSX in loaders/actions, but also to feel good on new greenfield projects looking to go all-in with Server Component Routes, `‚Äôuse client‚Äô` and `‚Äôuse server‚Äô` directives. They also explain how to solve the N+1 query problem in RSCs, inspired by GraphQL/DataLoader.

translations.en: La fonctionnalit√© est con√ßue pour √™tre adopt√©e de mani√®re incr√©mentielle en renvoyant du JSX dans les loaders/actions, mais aussi pour √™tre agr√©able sur les nouveaux projets greenfield souhaitant aller √† fond avec les Server Component Routes, les directives `‚Äôuse client‚Äô` et `‚Äôuse server‚Äô`. Ils expliquent √©galement comment r√©soudre le probl√®me de requ√™te N+1 dans les RSC, inspir√© par GraphQL/DataLoader.

fr.translation: La fonctionnalit√© est con√ßue pour une adoption progressive via le retour de JSX dans les loaders/actions, mais aussi pour les nouveaux projets souhaitant utiliser intensivement les Server Component Routes et les directives `'use client'`/`'use server'`. Ils expliquent √©galement comment r√©soudre le probl√®me des requ√™tes N+1 dans les RSC, inspir√© par GraphQL/DataLoader.
fr.reason: Content of a non-translatable 'inlineCode' element was changed. Source: '`‚Äôuse client‚Äô`', Translation: '`'use client'`'.

segments.source_content: [![Render Hooks](/emails/issues/235/renderhook.jpg)](https://github.com/brandonmcconnell/render-hooks)
**[Render Hooks](https://github.com/brandonmcconnell/render-hooks) and [With React](https://github.com/jacobparis/with-react)**

Looks like the Render Props pattern is making a comeback, with 2 new projects proposing to expose React core hooks in a render callback. This is a convenient trick in some situations, allowing you to "inline" a component while still respecting the rules of hooks, but it does not really solve any problem that can‚Äôt be solved by extracting a custom component. An interesting pattern to use sparingly.

translations.fr: Le pattern Render Props semble faire son retour, avec 2 nouveaux projets exposant les hooks React de base via un callback de rendu. C'est une astuce pratique dans certains cas pour "inliner" un composant tout en respectant les r√®gles des hooks, mais elle ne r√©sout pas de probl√®me insoluble par un composant personnalis√©. Un pattern int√©ressant √† utiliser avec parcimonie.
translations.en: Il semble que le pattern Render Props fasse son retour, avec 2 nouveaux projets proposant d'exposer les hooks React de base dans un callback de rendu. C'est une astuce pratique dans certaines situations, vous permettant d'"inliner" un composant tout en respectant les r√®gles des hooks, mais cela ne r√©sout pas vraiment de probl√®me qui ne pourrait √™tre r√©solu en extrayant un composant personnalis√©. Un pattern int√©ressant √† utiliser avec parcimonie.

segments.source_content:
- üí∏ [Product for Engineers - What engineers get wrong about communication](https://go.posthog.com/twir-may21)
- üëÄ [React Core PR \- `createStore()` skeleton API](https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/33215): Initial scaffolding work to implement the Concurrent Stores feature mentioned in the latest React Labs update. There‚Äôs no implementation yet, but I still find it interesting to check the signature/types of this upcoming API that should support both ad-hoc state updates and the reducer/actions pattern. What strikes me the most is that you can‚Äôt access the store value directly, apart from using the `use(store)` API, and this totally makes sense in a concurrent world. Remember, this is a work in progress, and things may change.
- üëÄ [React Core PRs \- `<SuspenseList>` being actively worked on](https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Afacebook%2Freact+SuspenseList&type=pullrequests&s=created&o=desc): It‚Äôs been a while since we last heard of this upcoming component that we thought would be in React 18\. It allows to coordinate Suspense boundaries and control their ‚Äúreveal order‚Äù (forwards/backwards/together).
- üëÄ [React Core PR \- Transition indicator \+ `onDefaultTransitionIndicator` API](https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/33162): A feature being worked on should allow giving user feedback while React transitions are in progress. The default React-DOM implementation should show a native browser spinner, but it‚Äôs possible to opt out or provide a custom feedback.
- üëÄ [SWC PR \- Initialize `@swc/react-compiler`](https://github.com/swc-project/swc/pull/10475): A new package to integrate the React Compiler for all SWC-based projects is coming. It will still use Babel under the hood ([details](https://github.com/oxc-project/oxc/issues/10048#issuecomment-2837628965)), but it‚Äôs possible to optimize by only running it on relevant files (see what [Next.js is doing](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/config/next-config-js/reactCompiler)), potentially using parallelization.
- üëÄ [Next.js PR \- Initial Segment Explorer devtool](https://github.com/vercel/next.js/pull/78858): The Next.js team started working on a tool to help you visualize parallel and interception route segments.
- üîê [Next.js Race Condition to Cache Poisoning \- CVE-2025-32421](https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-qpjv-v59x-3qc4): Low-severity Pages Router vulnerability, already patched.
- üì£ [Appwrite Sites: The open-source Vercel alternative](https://appwrite.io/blog/post/announcing-appwrite-sites): The AppWrite cloud platform can now deploy full-stack React meta-frameworks. It positions itself as a direct Vercel competitor, although there are differences (containers vs serverless). It‚Äôs a paid cloud product, but you can also self-host it for free.
- üìú [Concurrent Rendering](https://ui.dev/c/react/concurrent-rendering): Free interactive lesson on React transitions from the ui.dev course.
- üìú [Correctly infers from initial props](https://rena.to/blog/13): You don‚Äôt need to explicitly type your context value and can leverage type inference instead.
- üìú [Making Next.js Navigation Fast af](https://upstash.com/blog/fast-nextjs): Using React Router within your Next.js app works, but I doubt it‚Äôs a good idea, doesn‚Äôt permit you to use RSCs, and is likely to cause trouble if you use different routers on different pages.
- üìú [Mastering Focus Management in React with `flushSync`](https://www.epicreact.dev/mastering-focus-management-in-react-with-flush-sync-f5b38): By default, React uses batching and doesn‚Äôt flush state updates immediately to the DOM, and you can opt out of this behavior when needed.
- üìú [Preserving and Resetting State in React](https://www.epicreact.dev/preserving-and-resetting-state-in-react-l2dxl): Explains why conditionally wrapping a component may make it reset its state.
- üìú [Just F\*\*\*ing Use React](https://justfuckingusereact.com/): Entertaining read, also exists in a less profane [Just Use React](https://www.epicreact.dev/just-use-react-dk4e0) variant.
- üìú [The Past and Future of Render Optimization with React Context](https://newsletter.daishikato.com/p/the-past-and-future-of-render-optimization-with-react-context)
- üí∏ [Full-Stack Upgrade ‚Äì Build real apps with auth, orgs & file uploads: The Road to Next is your next step as a full-stack React developer.](https://www.road-to-next.com/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=this_week_in_react_1)
- üì¶ [Waku 0.23 \- Fine-grained component render modes](https://waku.gg/blog/fine-grained-router-components): Makes it possible to statically pre-render parts of a dynamic page. I find the API a bit confusing, but the idea looks cool and simpler than Next.js Partial Pre-Rendering.
- üì¶ [React-Scan 0.3.4 \- Scan for React performance issues](https://github.com/aidenybai/react-scan/releases/tag/v0.3.4): A release that takes the opportunity to announce upcoming features and the availability of the [extension on the Chrome store](https://chromewebstore.google.com/detail/react-scan/anmmhkomejbdklkhoiloeaehppaffmdf).
- üì¶ [React Aria \- May 19 Release](https://react-spectrum.adobe.com/releases/2025-05-19.html)
- üì¶ [React-Admin \- May 2025 Update \- 5.7 & 5.8](https://marmelab.com/blog/2025/05/21/react-admin-may-2025-update.html)
- üì¶ [StyleX 0.13 \- New `defineConsts` and `positionTry` APIs](https://stylexjs.com/blog/v0.13.0)
- üì¶ [Shopify Hydrogen 2025.05 \- Upgrades to React Router 7](https://hydrogen.shopify.dev/update/may-2025)
- üé• [Theo \- React Is the last framework](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P1FLEnKZTAE): Probably a quite controversial point of view that React runtime/syntax is less likely to change now (mainly due to AI). Innovation is moving an abstraction layer above with the React Compiler.
- üé• [Alem Tuzlak \- Server Componets (RSC) in react-router are... actually good?](http://epicweb.dev/tips/server-componets-rsc-in-react-router-are-actually-good~n3u4j)
- üéôÔ∏è [Syntax 902 \- Fullstack Cloudflare with React and Vite \- RedwoodSDK with Peter Pistorius](https://syntax.fm/show/902/fullstack-cloudflare-with-react-and-vite-redwood-sdk)
- üéôÔ∏è [Front-end Fire 95 \-TanStack DB & The Rise of the Tannerverse](https://front-end-fire.com/episodes/95/)

segments.source_content: ## üîÄ Other {#other}

- üëÄ [TC39 \- Agenda for the 108th meeting](https://github.com/tc39/agendas/blob/main/2025/05.md): Next week, another set of interesting proposals for JS could progress, some of them could become part of the standard: `using` keyword, `Error.isError()`.
- üìú [JavaScript's New Superpower: Explicit Resource Management](https://v8.dev/features/explicit-resource-management): Describes the `using` keyword mentioned above, already available in Chrome, and more importantly, in Node 24\.
- üìú [The Future of MCP is GraphQL](https://www.apollographql.com/blog/the-future-of-mcp-is-graphql): Apollo announcing their MCP server, explaining the alignment between GraphQL and AI needs.
- üìú [I think the ergonomics of generators is growing on me](https://macarthur.me/posts/generators/)
- üìú [Reports of Deno's Demise Have Been Greatly Exaggerated](https://deno.com/blog/greatly-exaggerated)
- üì¶ [Node 22.16 \- `node.config.json` support (experimental)](https://nodejs.org/en/blog/release/v22.16.0)
- üì¶ [Zod 4.0 \- faster, slimmer, more tsc-efficient, new Zod Mini export, localization and more](https://zod.dev/v4)
- üì¶ [Remotion Media Parser \- Universal lib based on WebCodecs to parse/decode/encode videos](https://www.remotion.dev/blog/media-parser)

translations.fr:
- üëÄ [TC39 - Ordre du jour de la 108e r√©union](https://github.com/tc39/agendas/blob/main/2025/05.md) : La semaine prochaine, un nouvel ensemble de propositions int√©ressantes pour JS pourrait progresser, certaines pouvant int√©grer le standard : mot-cl√© `using`, `Error.isError()`.
- üìú [Le nouveau super-pouvoir de JavaScript : la gestion explicite des ressources](https://v8.dev/features/explicit-resource-management) : D√©crit le mot-cl√© `using` mentionn√© ci-dessus, d√©j√† disponible dans Chrome, et surtout dans Node 24\.
- üìú [L'avenir du MCP est GraphQL](https://www.apollographql.com/blog/the-future-of-mcp-is-graphql) : Apollo annonce son serveur MCP, expliquant l'alignement entre GraphQL et les besoins de l'IA.
- üìú [L'ergonomie des g√©n√©rateurs commence √† me s√©duire](https://macarthur.me/posts/generators/)
- üìú [Les annonces de la disparition de Deno sont grandement exag√©r√©es](https://deno.com/blog/greatly-exaggerated)

- üì¶ [Remotion Media Parser - Librairie universelle bas√©e sur WebCodecs pour analyser/d√©coder/encoder des vid√©os](https://www.remotion.dev/blog/media-parser)
translations.en:
- üëÄ [TC39 - Agenda for the 108th meeting](https://github.com/tc39/agendas/blob/main/2025/05.md): La semaine prochaine, une nouvelle s√©rie de propositions int√©ressantes pour JS pourrait progresser, certaines pourraient devenir partie int√©grante du standard : mot-cl√© `using`, `Error.isError()`.
- üìú [JavaScript's New Superpower: Explicit Resource Management](https://v8.dev/features/explicit-resource-management): D√©crit le mot-cl√© `using` mentionn√© ci-dessus, d√©j√† disponible dans Chrome, et plus important encore, dans Node 24\.
- üìú [The Future of MCP is GraphQL](https://www.apollographql.com/blog/the-future-of-mcp-is-graphql): Apollo annonce son serveur MCP, expliquant l'alignement entre GraphQL et les besoins de l'IA.
- üìú [I think the ergonomics of generators is growing on me](https://macarthur.me/posts/generators/)
